articles.headline: This Social Club Runs on Crypto Tokens and Vibes
articles.snippet: Friends With Benefits is a V.I.P. lounge for crypto’s creative class. Is it empty hype or the future of friendship?
articles.abstract: Friends With Benefits is a V.I.P. lounge for crypto’s creative class. Is it empty hype or the future of friendship?
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, nine members of the crypto social club Friends With Benefits sat in the historic Bradbury Building in downtown Los Angeles, testing out a new beverage — a flavored, sparkling yerba maté that the group had developed with a coffee company.
articles.byline: By Erin Woo and Kevin Roose

articles.headline: Twitter Wants to Reinvent Itself, by Merging the Old With the New
articles.snippet: The company is undertaking a far-reaching effort to change how it works. For some, it is an echo of their early idealism and a vision for what the internet could have been.
articles.abstract: The company is undertaking a far-reaching effort to change how it works. For some, it is an echo of their early idealism and a vision for what the internet could have been.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2008, the handful of employees working for Twitter reached an impasse. Some were focused on preparing for a surge of new users to their social media platform. But one developer argued for another approach: Their platform, he said, shouldn’t be a platform at all.

articles.headline: Should Tech Stay or Go in Russia?
articles.snippet: Tech companies seem eager to support Ukraine, but how best to do that isn’t as clear.
articles.abstract: Tech companies seem eager to support Ukraine, but how best to do that isn’t as clear.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.

articles.headline: 15,000 Are Sheltering in Kyiv’s Subway
articles.snippet: People sleep three or four to a mattress and plastic food bags litter the scene, while mothers search endlessly on their phones for news of the war.
articles.abstract: People sleep three or four to a mattress and plastic food bags litter the scene, while mothers search endlessly on their phones for news of the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — As the escalator glides down the final few yards into the subway stop deep in Kyiv’s normally immaculate mass transit system, a sprawl of foam mattresses, suitcases and plastic bags filled with food comes into view. The space is surprisingly quiet, almost silent, despite the 200 or so people camped there to escape the bombing and artillery fire above.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario

articles.headline: Starbucks Is Moving to Oust Workers in Buffalo, Union Supporters Say
articles.snippet: Some employees who back unionization efforts have been told they must increase their work availability or leave. The company cites scheduling issues.
articles.abstract: Some employees who back unionization efforts have been told they must increase their work availability or leave. The company cites scheduling issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Workers at Starbucks stores in Buffalo are accusing the company of retaliating against union supporters by telling some of them they may have to leave the company if they cannot increase their work availability.

articles.headline: A War the Kremlin Tried to Disguise Becomes a Hard Reality for Russians
articles.snippet: Moscow posted a death toll from its attack on Ukraine for the first time, and Russians who long avoided politics are now grappling with the fact that their country is fighting a deadly conflict.
articles.abstract: Moscow posted a death toll from its attack on Ukraine for the first time, and Russians who long avoided politics are now grappling with the fact that their country is fighting a deadly conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — On Feb. 23, Razil Malikov, a tank driver in the Russian Army, called his family and said he would be home soon; his unit’s military drills in Crimea were just about wrapping up.
articles.byline: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski

articles.headline: First Ukraine City Falls as Russia Strikes More Civilian Targets
articles.snippet: Russian forces seized the southern city of Kherson and besieged other cities, with casualties and destruction mounting, as Western sanctions tightened their vise grip on Russia’s economy.
articles.abstract: Russian forces seized the southern city of Kherson and besieged other cities, with casualties and destruction mounting, as Western sanctions tightened their vise grip on Russia’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ODESSA, Ukraine — Russian forces on Wednesday seized the first major Ukrainian city in their onslaught, the strategic port of Kherson, as they stepped up bombardment of civilian targets across the country, put other cities under siege and pushed to encircle and cut off the capital, Kyiv.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Jan. 6 Committee Lays Out Potential Criminal Charges Against Trump
articles.snippet: In a court filing, the panel said there was enough evidence to suggest that the former president might have engaged in a criminal conspiracy as he fought to remain in office.
articles.abstract: In a court filing, the panel said there was enough evidence to suggest that the former president might have engaged in a criminal conspiracy as he fought to remain in office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol said on Wednesday that there was enough evidence to conclude that former President Donald J. Trump and some of his allies might have conspired to commit fraud and obstruction by misleading Americans about the outcome of the 2020 election and attempting to overturn the result.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Can Workers Climb the Career Ladder From Outside the Office?
articles.snippet: Translating opportunities for networking, mentoring and advancement to the virtual world isn’t easy.
articles.abstract: Translating opportunities for networking, mentoring and advancement to the virtual world isn’t easy.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his internship at a major bank last summer, Costa Kosmidis spent most of his time working remotely. The bank did its best to help interns bridge the distance, he said, including by putting into practice “an open ‘virtual door’ policy” that made senior staff readily available by phone or email for job-related queries and career advice.

articles.headline: Fact and Mythmaking Blend in Ukraine’s Information War
articles.snippet: Experts say stories like the Ghost of Kyiv and Snake Island, both of questionable veracity, are propaganda or morale boosters, or perhaps both.
articles.abstract: Experts say stories like the Ghost of Kyiv and Snake Island, both of questionable veracity, are propaganda or morale boosters, or perhaps both.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Stuart A. Thompson and Davey Alba
